content.description: The temperature of water in a tub at time t is modeled by a strictly increasing, twice-differentiable function W, where W(t) is measured in degrees Fahrenheit and t is measured in minutes. At time t=0, the temperature of the water is 55oF. The water is heated for 30 minutes, beginning at time t=0. Values of W(t) at selected times t for the first 20 minutes are given in the table above.
content.question: For 20≤t≤25, the function W that models the water temperature has first derivative given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>W</mi> <mo>'</mo> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0.</mn> <mtext>4</mtext> <msqrt> <mi>t</mi> </msqrt> <mtext> cos</mtext> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mn>0.0</mn> <mtext>6</mtext> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4716@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Based on the model, what is the temperature of the water at time t=25?

frqParts.text: For 20≤t≤25, the function W that models the water temperature has first derivative given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>W</mi> <mo>'</mo> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0.</mn> <mtext>4</mtext> <msqrt> <mi>t</mi> </msqrt> <mtext> cos</mtext> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mn>0.0</mn> <mtext>6</mtext> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4716@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Based on the model, what is the temperature of the water at time t=25?

topic.text: 6.5: Interpreting the Behavior of Accumulation Functions Involving Area

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Identify how mathematical characteristics or properties of functions are related in different representations.
